0.crop_desc: MTU 1010, also known as Cottondora Sannalu, is a medium-duration (115–120 days) rice variety widely cultivated in Telangana during both Kharif and Rabi seasons. It is well-suited for rainfed upland and irrigated ecosystems, offering an average yield of 22–24 quintals per acre under Kharif conditions.
0.cultivation_overview: The cultivation process begins with land preparation, involving deep ploughing and leveling to ensure uniform water distribution. Certified seeds are soaked and incubated before sowing in well-prepared nursery beds. After 20–25 days, healthy seedlings are transplanted into the main field at a spacing of 20 cm x 15 cm, with 2–3 seedlings per hill. Basal fertilizers, including nitrogen, phosphorus, and potassium, are applied during field preparation. Subsequent fertilizer applications are scheduled at tillering and panicle initiation stages. Regular irrigation, weed management, and pest control are essential throughout the growth period. As the crop approaches maturity, irrigation is reduced to facilitate drying. Harvesting is done when 80–85% of the grains turn golden yellow. Post-harvest practices include threshing, cleaning, drying to a moisture content of 14%, and storage in clean, dry, and pest-free facilities. Regular monitoring of stored grains is recommended to prevent infestations. MTU 1010's adaptability and stable yields make it a preferred choice among farmers in Telangana. However, it's important to note that in certain regions, such as the East Godavari district in Andhra Pradesh, the cultivation of MTU 1010 has been discouraged due to market preferences and grain quality considerations.

tasks: Select certified MTU 1010 seeds.
Soak seeds in clean water for 24 hours.
Incubate soaked seeds in a wet cloth/gunny bag for 24–36 hours until sprouting.
Treat sprouted seeds with fungicide (e.g., carbendazim 2g/kg).
Prepare nursery beds (1/20th of the main field area) with FYM and level.
Sow sprouted seeds evenly in nursery beds.
Irrigate the nursery lightly.
Continue nursery irrigation as needed (keep moist, not waterlogged).
Begin the first ploughing of the main field, mixing well-rotted cow dung (FYM) or compost into the soil before planting to make the soil more fertile and help crops grow better.
notes: FYM – Farm yard manure
First Ploughing is done before any fertilizers or water are added.

tasks: Monitor the nursery for pests/diseases.
Second ploughing of the main field.
notes: Second ploughing is done after applying water (puddling) or after adding manure or fertilizers.

tasks: Remove weeds from the nursery if present.
Level the main field after ploughing.
Repair bunds and field channels for irrigation/drainage.
Maintain nursery moisture.
notes: Check and fix the soil walls (bunds) and water paths (channels) in the field so that water stays where needed and drains out properly when required. This helps in better irrigation and prevents water loss or flooding.
Bunds are soil walls to hold water in the field, and channels are small paths to bring water in or drain it out.

tasks: Continue nursery care (irrigation, pest check).
Flood the main field, begin puddling (churn soil for transplanting).
notes: Puddling: Puddling is a special method used mostly in rice farming to prepare the soil before planting seedlings, mixing soil and water to make a soft, muddy, and smooth layer in the field.
Churning of soil: Churning of soil means mixing and turning the soil thoroughly, usually with water, using tools like ploughs, rotavators, or even by hand (in small beds).

tasks: Level the puddled field for even water distribution.
Allow the field to settle.
Final nursery irrigation before pulling seedlings.
Pull 20–25 day-old seedlings from the nursery, bundle, and keep roots moist.
Transplant seedlings at 20 x 15 cm or 20 x 20 cm spacing, 3–5 cm deep, 2–3 seedlings/hill.
Apply basal fertilizer (full P, half K, 1/3 N) during/after transplanting.
Maintain shallow water (5 cm) for seedling establishment.
notes: After planting the seedlings in the main field, keep checking if they look healthy. If they seem dry, weak, or yellow, they may be struggling. Give enough water and care to help them grow well.
Transplant shock happens when young plants (like rice seedlings) are moved from one place (nursery) to another (main field), and they struggle to adjust.

tasks: Keep field moist, check for seedling establishment.
First manual/mechanical weeding (20–30 DAT).
notes: DAT – days after transplanting

tasks: Monitor for early pests (stem borer, leaf folder) and diseases.
Maintain water at 5–7 cm.
Top-dress with nitrogen and potassium at active tillering.
notes: Top-dressing is when the rice plant starts growing more new stems (around 25–30 days after transplanting), lightly sprinkle nitrogen and potassium fertilizer on the soil near the plants. This is called top dressing — it gives the crop extra nutrients to grow strong and produce more grains.

tasks: Second weeding if needed.
Monitor for pests (BPH, stem borer) and apply control if needed.
Continue irrigation as per requirement.
Apply the second split of nitrogen and potassium at panicle initiation.
notes: Panicle initiation, in crops (especially rice), means the stage when the plant starts forming the part that will grow into the grain cluster (called the panicle), usually deep inside the stem. The point when the plant begins preparing to grow grains it's like the first sign that the plant is getting ready to make rice.

tasks: Check for micronutrient deficiencies (zinc, iron) and correct if needed.
notes: Micronutrients: Micronutrients are essential nutrients that rice plants need in very small amounts, but they are very important for healthy growth and grain production.

tasks: Maintain regular irrigation (5–7 cm water).

week_11_to_13.title: Flowering, Grain Filling, and Pest/Disease Vigilance

tasks: Maintain water at 5–7 cm during flowering.
Monitor for diseases like blast, sheath blight, and BPH.
Continue pest/disease monitoring and apply fungicides/insecticides if necessary.
Keep enough water in the field when the rice grains form, so the crop doesn't dry out and yield low.
Reduce irrigation as the crop matures.
Monitor for late pests/diseases.
Stop watering the field 7 to 10 days before harvesting so the plants can dry properly and the grains become hard and ready to cut.
Check grain maturity (80–85% golden yellow, hard grains).
Arrange labor/machinery for harvest.
Cut the crop early in the morning when it's cool, so the rice grains don't fall off the plant and get wasted.
Stack cut plants for 1–2 days for uniform drying.
After cutting the crop, separate the grains from the plants (threshing) and remove dust, husk, or stones to keep the grains clean and ready for storage or sale.
Sun-dry grains to 14% moisture and store in clean, dry, pest-free containers.
notes: 14% moisture means that out of the total weight of the grain, 14% is water and the rest is the dry matter of the rice.

0.conclusion: This schedule ensures timely operations for each stage of MTU 1010 rice, from nursery preparation to post-harvest techniques, maximizing yield and grain quality. Adjustments may be made for local weather, field conditions, or direct seeding methods. Regular monitoring and timely management of water, nutrients, weeds, pests, and diseases are crucial throughout the crop cycle.

1.crop_desc: Sannalu (KNM), officially known as Kunaram Sannalu (KNM 118), is a high-yielding, long slender grain rice variety developed by the Agricultural Research Station, Kunaram, and released in Telangana in 2015. It was specifically bred as an alternative to the widely grown MTU 1010, addressing issues such as susceptibility to pests, diseases, and grain shattering that affected the older variety. Kunaram Sannalu is well-suited for both kharif and rabi seasons, with a crop duration of about 120–125 days in kharif and 125–130 days in rabi. The plants reach a height of 100–106 cm and are less prone to lodging and grain shattering at harvest compared to MTU 1010, making them easier to manage and harvest.
1.cultivation_overview: This variety stands out for its high yield potential, producing 7–8 tonnes per hectare under good management, and has good test weight and grain quality. The grains are translucent, long, and slender, with excellent head rice recovery and cooking quality, fetching premium prices in both government procurement and private markets. Sannalu (KNM 118) is also tolerant to leaf and neck blast diseases, making it more resilient and reducing the need for chemical controls. It is widely accepted by farmers, millers, traders, and consumers in Telangana due to its reliable yield, grain quality, and market demand. The variety adapts well to late sowing in kharif and is suitable for direct seeding methods, providing flexibility for farmers in different agro-climatic conditions. Overall, Sannalu (KNM) is a profitable and sustainable choice for rice cultivation in Telangana, contributing to increased productivity and farmer income.

week_1.title: Seed Selection, Soaking, and Nursery Preparation

tasks: Select high-quality, certified Sannalu (KNM) seeds.
Soak seeds in clean water for 24 hours.
notes: Sannalu (KNM) seeds are good quality if, select clean, uniform, plump seeds without damage or discoloration, and test their germination by soaking a sample in water then good seeds will mostly sink and sprout well.

Treat sprouted seeds with recommended fungicide to prevent nursery diseases.
Prepare nursery beds (about 1/20th of main field area).
Incorporate well-rotted farmyard manure (FYM) or compost.
Sow sprouted seeds evenly and water lightly.
Maintain nursery moisture (not flooded).
Begin first ploughing of the main field.
Monitor nursery for pests and diseases.
Conduct second ploughing of the main field.
Remove weeds from nursery.
Level the main field.
Repair bunds and create water channels.
Keep nursery beds moist.
Continue nursery care.
Flood and puddle the main field to soften soil.
Level the puddled field for uniform water distribution.
Allow field to settle.
Give final watering to nursery before transplanting.
Uproot 21–25-day-old seedlings from nursery.
Bundle and keep roots moist.
Transplant seedlings at 20 x 20 cm spacing, 2–3 seedlings per hill, 5 cm deep.
Apply half of the potassium and all phosphorus as basal fertilizer.
Add organic manure if not already done.
Maintain a shallow water layer (5 cm) in the field to help seedlings establish.
Ensure seedlings are well established.
Maintain water at 5–7 cm.
Conduct first weeding (20–30 days after transplanting) by hand or mechanical weeder.
Monitor for pests and diseases.
Continue regular irrigation.
Apply first top-dressing of nitrogen and remaining potassium at the tillering stage.
Perform second weeding if necessary.
Watch for pests (stem borers, leaf folders) and treat as needed.
Maintain water at 5–7 cm.
Apply second split of nitrogen at panicle initiation.
Check for nutrient deficiencies (e.g., zinc).
Continue regular irrigation.
Maintain water at 5–7 cm during flowering.
Monitor for pests (brown plant hopper, blast disease).
Use pesticides only if necessary.
Avoid water stress; keep field moist.
Gradually reduce irrigation as crop matures.
Drain field 7–10 days before harvest.
Check if grains are golden yellow and hard.
Prepare for harvest.
Harvest by cutting plants close to the ground.
Stack bundles upright for 1–2 days to dry.
Thresh to separate grains from straw.
Sun-dry grains to about 14% moisture.
Store in clean, dry, pest-free containers.

1.conclusion: Key Considerations for Sannalu (KNM) Rice variety: Disease Management: Sannalu (KNM) is generally resilient but monitor for local disease pressures and apply fungicides only as recommended. Nutrient Management: Follow soil test-based fertilizer recommendations for best results. Water Management: Consistent moisture is crucial, especially during tillering and grain filling. Adaptability: Sannalu (KNM) is suitable for both kharif and rabi seasons and adapts well to traditional and mechanized farming methods. This weekly schedule for KNN rice variety ensures timely and efficient management of Sannalu rice, maximizing yield and grain quality. Adjustments may be needed based on local weather, field conditions, or if direct seeding is used. Regular monitoring and timely interventions for water, nutrients, pests, and diseases are essential throughout the crop cycle.

2.crop_desc: Telangana Sona (RNR 15048) is a premium, short-duration rice variety developed by Professor Jaya Shankar, Telangana State Agricultural University(PJTSAU), and is now widely cultivated in Telangana and neighboring states. This variety matures in about 120–125 days and is known for its high yield potential of 6,500–7,000 kg per hectare under good management. The grains are short, slender, super fine, and translucent, cooking into soft, fluffy, and non-sticky rice with a  naturally sweet taste and pleasant aroma, making it highly preferred by consumers in both domestic and export markets. Telangana Sona stands out for its strong resistance to blast disease, which reduces crop losses and the need for fungicides, and it offers a high head rice recovery rate of over 67%, benefiting both farmers and rice millers.
2.cultivation_overview: A key health advantage of Telangana Sona is its low glycemic index (GI ~51), making it a healthier choice for people with diabetes and those looking to manage blood sugar levels. It is also higher in protein and dietary fiber compared to regular varieties, low in fat, and free from added sugars, supporting a balanced and nutritious diet. Telangana Sona adapts well to both kharif and Rabi seasons, performs reliably under late sowing and various agro-climatic conditions, and is suitable for both traditional and modern farming methods, including direct seeding and mechanized cultivation. With its combination of high yield, disease resistance, superior grain quality, health benefits, and strong market demand, Telangana Sona (RNR 15048) is a profitable and sustainable choice for farmers and a healthy, tasty option for consumers.

week_1.title: Nursery Sowing and Main Field Preparation

tasks: Select good Telangana Sona seeds
Soak seeds in clean water for 24 hours
notes: Good Telangana Sona seeds are clean, healthy, certified seeds of the RNR 15048 variety that give strong and uniform crop growth

tasks: Drain water and keep seeds in a wet cloth or bag for 1–2 days to sprout
Mix sprouted seeds with a little fungicide to protect from diseases
notes: If there is blast disease, spray tricyclazole at 200 grams per acre (or 1 gram per liter of water) on the affected crop and repeat after 10–15 days if needed. Always follow label instructions and use clean water for spraying

tasks: Prepare nursery beds (about 1/20th of your main field)
Mix in well-rotted cow dung (FYM) or compost
Sow the sprouted seeds evenly
Water the nursery lightly
notes: FYM – farm yard manure

tasks: Water nursery as needed (keep moist, not flooded)
Start the first ploughing of the main field
Check the nursery for pests or diseases
Do the second ploughing of the main field
Remove weeds from the nursery, if present
Level the main field after ploughing
Repair bunds (field borders) and make water channels
Keep the nursery moist
Continue nursery care
Flood the main field and puddle (churn) the soil to make it soft
Level the puddled field for even water
Let the field settle
Give the last watering to the nursery before pulling the seedlings
Carefully pull 21–25 day-old seedlings from the nursery
Bundle and keep roots moist
Transplant seedlings in the main field at 20 x 20 cm spacing, 2–3 seedlings per spot, 5 cm deep
Apply half potassium and all phosphorus as basal fertilizer
Add organic manure or compost if not already done
notes: Basal fertilizer is the nutrient applied to the soil before or at planting to help young plants grow strong from the start

tasks: After planting, keep a thin layer of water (about ankle deep) about 5 cm in the field so the seedlings can stand and grow well
Check that the seedlings are standing well
Keep water at 5–7 cm
Do the first weeding by hand or weeder (20–30 days after transplanting)
Observe for pests and diseases of the crop
Continue regular watering of the crop
Add the first split of nitrogen and the remaining potassium as top dressing (at tillering stage)
notes: Top-dressing is when the rice plant starts growing more new stems (around 25–30 days after transplanting), lightly sprinkle nitrogen and potassium fertilizer on the soil near the plants. This is called top dressing — it gives the crop extra nutrients to grow strong and produce more grains

tasks: Do a second weeding if needed
Watch for pests (stem borers, leaf folders) and treat if needed
Maintain water at 5–7 cm
Add the second split of nitrogen (at the panicle initiation stage)
Check for yellowing or stunted growth (zinc deficiency) and apply zinc if needed
Continue regular irrigation
Keep water at 5–7 cm during flowering
Watch for pests (brown plant hopper, blast disease)
Apply pesticides only if needed
Avoid water stress; keep the field moist
Reduce irrigation as crop matures
Drain field 7–10 days before harvest
Check if most grains are golden yellow and hard
Arrange for harvesting tools or labor
Harvest crop by cutting plants close to ground
Stack bundles upright for 1–2 days to dry
Thresh (separate grains from straw) using a thresher or by beating
Sun-dry grains until hard and dry (about 14% moisture-hard to bite, not soft)
Store in clean, dry, pest-free bags or bins

2.conclusion: This schedule ensures timely operations for each stage of Telangana Sona rice, from nursery preparation to post-harvest techniques, maximizing yield and grain quality. Adjustments may be made for local weather, field conditions, or direct seeding methods. Regular monitoring and timely management of water, nutrients, weeds, pests, and diseases are crucial throughout the crop cycle.
